There is a number of services for creating digital constitutions and voting polls. For example OneClickOrgs - a platform to create digital constitutions, and Loomio - Loomio - allowing communities and organisations to vote when collective decisions are to be made.

These, and similar services at the moment store the history of votes or amendments to the constitution in a centralised way - either on the server provided by the software providers or on a company or community server. It basically means that the history of these actions can be changed by a central authority.

Both Loomio and OneClickOrgs are open source and have have a user friendly interface. We have discussed take these or similar existing web applications with existing user interface and make them talk to block chains.

Loomio and OneClockOrgs (and equivalents) at the moment store the history of votes or amendments to the constitution in a centralised way - either on the server provided by the software providers or on a company or community server. It basically means that the history of these actions can be changed by a central authority.
Applying block chain technology to these cases will allow the history of actions taken by the users almost impossible to fake.
Applying block chain technology to these cases will allow the history of actions taken by the users almost impossible to fake which, for example, makes the digital constitutions more legally robust.

I have mentioned decentralised and centralised databases, however, even if the block chain is not massively decentralised and used within a company or an association, it still provides much better transparency - all the changes (votes, amendments) will be recorded in the block chain and if the blockchain will be replaced by another block chain it will also show.
